DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

Italy COVID-19 total cases rose to 41035 (Prev. 35713) and death toll increased to 3405 to (Prev. 2978). (Newswires)

US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose to 10442 (Prev. 7038) and death toll rose to 150 (Prev. 97). (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 total cases 3268 (Prev. 2689) and death toll increased to 144 (Prev. 99). (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said they are working to get money to Americans within three weeks and that the Treasury and Fed working around the clock on virus response. In related news, US Senators are considering more than the USD 1,000 direct payments to Americans that was previously mentioned and are looking at offering two checks of USD 1,200 per adult, according to FBN sources. (Fox Business News)

NY Governor Cuomo said a lockdown is not going to happen, although he also noted the city is only 2-3 weeks from running out of certain hospital supplies and called upon military help for fighting coronavirus. (Newswires)

Russian President Putin and Chinese President Xi agreed to deepen cooperation on developing a coronavirus medicine, according to IFAX citing the Kremlin. (Newswires)

Bank of England cut Bank Rate to 0.10% from 0.25% in a unanimous emergency move and increased government bonds and corporate bond holdings by GBP 200bln to GBP 645bln, while it stated that the coronavirus will result in an economic shock that is sharp and large. Furthermore, the majority of additional asset purchases will comprise UK government bonds which will be completed as soon as is operationally possible and it voted unanimously to enlarge the TFSME scheme, financed by the issuance of central bank reserves. (Newswires)

BoE Governor Bailey said bank has scope to move further if required and that the time to act was now, while he rejected criticism that the move was monetary financing. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said Chancellor Sunak is to announce worker package support measures on Friday, while reports later noted that Chancellor Sunak is expected to announce ‘unprecedented’ support package on Friday including wage subsidies and tax cuts, in addition to the already announced GBP 20bln support and GBP 330bln loan guarantee scheme. (Newswires/FT)

UK has put the military on standby amid coronavirus, while there were other reports that UK supermarkets are expected to receive police support when London is placed into a lockdown according to sources. However, a PM Johnson spokesperson said there is zero prospect of any restriction being placed on travel in or out of London. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

China is to step up fiscal stimulus including infrastructure investment (such as 5G networks) and is considering plans to cut its 2020 growth target to as low as 5% from 6% agreed in December. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson spokesperson said the UK has been in close contact with EU to continue to progress negotiations, while European Commission said the EU-UK negotiations on ties following Brexit will be brought forward even in the current circumstances. (Newswires)

 

FX

SARB cut Repo Rate by 100bps to 5.25% vs. Exp. 50bps to 5.75% via a unanimous decision and stated that monetary policy on its own cannot reduce fiscal risks. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US President Trump said at an appropriate time he will get involved in the oil market dispute, while a separate source report suggested US officials are looking at intervening in the Russia-Saudi dispute and possibility of imposing sanctions on the Russians. (Newswires/WSJ)

Saudi Aramco Official said Co. will carry on reducing operation levels at local refineries in April and May to bolster export potential. (Newswires)

Texas is mulling curtailing oil production for the first time in decades, according to WSJ citing sources. (WSJ)

US Department of Energy has asked Congress for USD 3bln to fund the purchase of 77mln bbls of oil for the SPR, while there were separate report that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin suggested to buy USD 10bln-20bln of oil at lower prices. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Stocks made gains after recent sell-offs, meanwhile, the Dollar’s rally continued, with the DX rising above 102. Following a severe drop off on Wednesday, WTI posted its largest-ever percentage price gain, rebounding with risk appetite, for the time being, and also finding support from the US SPR moving forward with its purchasing plans, furthermore, Texas is reportedly gearing up to curtail production in what would be the first time in decades. The selling pressures also abated in the government bond complex too, with the TPLEX bull steepening. Aside from selling reprieve, desks noted the latest monetary stimulus measures, and anticipation of large fiscal measures, as supporting appetite for assets that aren’t just the US dollar: ECB announced EUR 750bln QE package; BoE cut its interest rate to effective lower bound and initiated fresh QE; Fed announces extended swap lines and new mutual fund backstop funding facility and the RBA also cut rates in tandem with its first-ever QE announcement. On a broader theme, US President Trump said he does not want government aid to go to buybacks, noting he is not happy with buybacks.  Trump later added that he would support the government an equity stake in some companies, saying aid is coming to airlines, cruise operators and hotels. Gilead (GILD) saw choppy trade amid US President Trump's coronavirus briefing which saw the name fall slightly as Trump made suggestions to other drugs being potentially used to help treat coronavirus patients, although quickly spiked on comments of promising therapies produced by GILD, albeit gains were short-lived. SPX +0.66% at 2,414, NDX +1.58% at 7,289, DJIA +0.95% at 20,087. T-note futures (M0) settled 1 point 4+ ticks higher at 135-07.

The TPLEX bull steepened after a recent acute sell-off in duration, alongside a bounce in equities. Desks note the improved risk sentiment and incoming fiscal and monetary stimulus has likely put a pause in forced liquidations in DM bonds. Furthermore, the Fed has been ramping up its Treasury purchases – with USD 100bln scheduled for purchase across Thursday and Friday. A large deluge of IG corporate supply didn’t buck the trend either after recent dry spells. By settlement, 10s -0.11bps at 1.147%, 2s -0.08bps at 0.448%, leaving the 2s10s at 69.20.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 19th March 2020: Another day, another monetary bazooka
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

19th March 2020: Another day, another monetary bazooka

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: ECB launches EUR 750bln PEPP; Fed announces extended central bank swap lines and money market facility; BoE cuts to 0.1% and launches QE; SNB holds rates; RBA cuts by 25bps; jobless claims spike and Philly Fed tumbles.
  • COMING UP: Data: US Existing Home Sales, German Producer Prices. Event: China LPR (1 & 5 year)

MARKET WRAP:

Stocks made gains after recent sell-offs, meanwhile, the Dollar’s rally continued, with the DX rising above 102. Following a severe drop off on Wednesday, WTI posted its largest-ever percentage price gain, rebounding with risk appetite, for the time being, and also finding support from the US SPR moving forward with its purchasing plans, furthermore, Texas is reportedly gearing up to curtail production in what would be the first time in decades. The selling pressures also abated in the government bond complex too, with the TPLEX bull steepening. Aside from selling reprieve, desks noted the latest monetary stimulus measures, and anticipation of large fiscal measures, as supporting appetite for assets that aren’t just the US dollar: ECB announced EUR 750bln QE package; BoE cut its interest rate to effective lower bound and initiated fresh QE; Fed announces extended swap lines and new mutual fund backstop funding facility; RBA cut. Meanwhile, the US is soon to get confirmation on the latest stimulus package which is said to be more than USD 1.0trln, while UK Chancellor Sunak is set to announce even further measures on Friday. The stimulus will be much appreciated given the cliff the global economy is currently falling off, note that weekly jobless claims ramped higher, in what is expected to be the first of many chunky prints, while the Philly Fed posted its largest-ever drop.

COVID-19:

US MEASURES: Senator Majority Leader McConnel is set to announce the Phase 3 stimulus package later on Thursday. The figure floating around is that it will be worth USD 1.3trln, with USD 300bln of that composed of delayed tax payments to the IRS. US President Trump tweeted that he only signed the Defense Production Act (DPA) to combat the “Chinese Virus” should the US need to invoke it in a worst-case scenario in the future, although he added that hopefully there will be no need. House Speaker Pelosi later said that she hopes he enforces the act as the US faces a large medical supply shortage.

LONDON / UK: UK Chancellor Sunak is expected to announce an ‘unprecedented’ support package, including wage subsidies and tax cuts, on Friday, in addition to the already announced GBP 20bln support and GBP 330bln loan guarantee scheme, according to the FT. PM Johnson’s spokesperson announced that there is “zero” prospect of any restriction being place on travel in or out of London. Meanwhile, Whitehall sources, cited by Sky News, said most shops could close and transport could be restricted in London by the weekend under plans being considered by UK Government. Furthermore, Transport for London is adjusting its service operations in which it will shut the Waterloo & City Line and close up to 40 stations, as well as suspend the night tube and night overground although night buses will still operate for essential journeys. The UK has also put the military on standby amid coronavirus; supermarkets are also expected to receive police support when London is placed into a lockdown, sources reported. Regarding fiscal support, some UK Senior Tory MPs (Duncan Smith/Jenkin/Clarke) are demanding immediate government action on pay/jobs support, against criticism that the Government’s announced measures will take too long to become effective. Later in the session, the UK Health official said the pressure on the health service in London will increase, where intensive care units will be first to see the pressure.

EUROPEAN MEASURES: German Ministers are yet to sign off on the EUR 40bln support package for small/medium Co's, could be in excess of EUR 40bln, according to Gov't sources. Furthermore, Handelsblatt's sources reported the German government wants to apply an exception to the debt brake rule that could happen at the Cabinet meeting on Monday. The Decision must be granted by the majority of Bundestag members, however. The article also mentioned that for small businesses, equipment aids worth several thousand Euros are being discussed. Italy announced it is to extend virus lockdown measures, with an extension of school closures beyond April 3rd. French Interior Minister says the Government will extend the lockdown period if it is necessary.

SHORT SALE BANS: As several European exchanges implement short sale bans, regulator Bafin announced Stoxx 50 & 600, MSCI Europe and MSCI EU are all exempt from short-selling prohibitions; restrictions apply to index-related instruments only if shares covered by prohibitions exceed respective demand thresholds expressed as a % of their weight; instruments related to index Euro Stoxx banks are also exempt from short-selling prohibitions.

CHINA: China to step up fiscal stimulus including infrastructure investment (such as 5G networks) and is considering plans to cut its 2020 growth target to as low as 5% from 6% agreed in Dec

CASE COUNT – figures provided today against previous provided Thursday: US total cases 10,442 (prev. 7,038), death toll 150 (prev. 97); NY State cases 4,152 (prev. 2,914). UK total cases 3268 (prev. 2,689), death toll 144 (prev. 99). ITALY total cases 41,035 (prev. 35,713), death toll 3405 (prev. 2978). FRANCE total cases 10,995 (prev. 9,134), death toll 372 (prev. 264). GERMANY total cases 13,944 (prev. 9,257). SPAIN total cases 17,147 (prev. 13,716); death toll 767 (prev. 558). NETHERLANDS total cases 2,460 (prev. 2051). SOUTH KOREA total cases 8,565 (prev. 8,413); death toll 91 (prev. 84).

CENTRAL BANKS

FED USD SWAP LINES: The Fed announced the establishment of temporary US dollar swap lines to an extended group of central banks. Supporting the provision of up to USD 60bln each for Reserve Bank of Australia, the Banco Central do Brasil, the Bank of Korea, the Banco de Mexico, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and the Sveriges Riksbank. While offering USD 30bln each to the Danmarks Nationalbank, the Norges Bank, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand. The Fed notes that these liquidity arrangements will be in place for six months; the existing swap lines with the BoC, BoE, BoJ, ECB and SNB remain. The move comes amid the global scramble for dollars, exhibited in the likes of xccy basis swaps widening, amongst other indicators, which has seen many amplify their calls on the Fed to increase the scope of its swap line agreements, which theoretically, should see funding pressures in global markets ease.

FED MONEY MARKET MUTUAL FUND LIQUIDITY FACILITY: Otherwise known as MMLF, was announced overnight. The facility (previously used in the 2008/09 crisis) will provide loans to financial institutions secured by high-quality assets purchased by the financial institutions from money market mutual funds. This latest facility is aimed at supporting funds amid the market turmoil which will assist them in meeting redemption demand from households and other investors. Furthermore, the Treasury will provide USD 10bln, from its Exchange Stabilization Fund, of credit protection to the Fed.

NY FED OPERATIONS: All USD 12.5bln bids in the 14-day Term repo operation (45bln offered) were accepted, meanwhile both the O/N operations were significantly undersubscribed too. As GC rates remain subdued, the lack of take up in Fed’s operation makes sense given PDs can access funding markets at rates within the Fed’s target range – likely a result of the Fed’s aggressive actions in credit markets.

ECB PEPP: ECB announced EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) in which it will launch a new temporary asset purchase programme of private and public sector securities to counter serious risks to monetary policy transmission mechanism. Purchases will be conducted until the end of 2020 and will include all the asset categories eligible under the existing asset purchase programme (APP). Furthermore, the GC said it is fully prepared to raise the size of programmes, as well as adjust composition by as much as necessary and for as long as needed. A waiver of the eligibility requirements for securities issued by the Greek government will be granted for purchases under PEPP. Elsewhere, ECB TLTRO3 3rd allotment had a strong take-up of EUR 115bln (prev. EUR 97.7bln).

ECB'S LAGARDE said extraordinary times require extraordinary action, while she added there are no limits to our commitment to the Euro and are determined to use full potential of all our tools within our mandate.

ECB’S VILLEROY said ECB is absolutely determined to fight fragmentation risk between Eurozone countries and noted it will buy more bonds if needed in this exceptional period, while he also stated that French banks are solid and do not need nationalisation.

BANK OF ENGLAND CUTS BANK RATE TO 0.1% FROM 0.25% in a unanimous emergency move; increasing govts bonds and corp bond holding by GBP 200bln to GBP 645bln, saying COVID will result in economic shock that is sharp and large. It, therefore, voted unanimously to increase the Bank of England’s holdings of UK government bonds and sterling non-financial investment-grade corporate bonds by £200 billion to a total of £645 billion, financed by the issuance of central bank reserves. Voted unanimously that the Bank of England should enlarge the TFSME scheme, financed by the issuance of central bank reserves. The majority of additional asset purchases will comprise UK government bonds; will be completed as soon as it is operationally possible.

BOE GOVERNOR BAILEY said the bank has scope to move further if required; time to act was now; rejects criticism that the move was monetary financing. Bailey said it is important that it has not scheduled anymore QE, and to move when needed. Adding that global central bankers are in very close contact. Bailey also stressed that negative interest rates not compatible with getting banks to lend.

SNB LEFT POLICY RATE UNCHANGED AT -0.75% as expected, CHF is “even more highly valued” vs. Prev. “highly valued”; SNB is intervening even more in FX markets. SNB is raising the exemption threshold as of 1 April 2020, thus reducing the negative interest burden on the banking system. The threshold factor will increase from 25 to 30. SNB is examining whether a relaxation of the countercyclical capital buffer would be possible despite the risks on the mortgage and real estate markets. The SNB will take additional steps to ensure liquidity as necessary. Even under this assumption, however, GDP growth is likely to be negative for the year as a whole. The return to normality from the second half of the year onwards could thereafter be reflected in strong positive growth in 2021.

SNB GOVERNOR JORDAN: SNB can cut interest rates further in the future but it is unfavourable at the moment, Switzerland is not a currency manipulator; SNB does not intervene to get an advantage vs. other countries. Notes, there is no co-ordinated measures with other central banks. Talks are ongoing with Swiss Govt but its too early to give details of further supportive steps.

RBA LOWERED CASH RATE TARGET BY 25BPS to 0.25% and announced to buy government bonds in the secondary market as speculated, which will commence on Friday. Furthermore, the RBA announced to offer 3yr funding (TFF) to authorized deposit-taking institutions with the facility valued at least AUD 90bln, while it stated that banks will have access to additional low-cost funding if they expand lending to businesses.

DATA:

JOBLESS CLAIMS: rose to 281K from 211K, above the expected 220K and above the forecast range. Pantheon notes next week’s numbers will be an “order of magnitude worse” with this week’s figures taking a hit from the closures of bars and restaurants. “Our tentative forecast for next week is two-to-three million claims. We hope that will be the single worst week, but we can’t be sure. Even if we’re right, the drop in April nonfarm payrolls is likely to be of the order of five million,” the consultancy adds, noting that the shock will be so great that fiscal stimulus will be inevitable, suggesting a USD 2trln package aimed at households and SMEs.

PHILLY FED INDEX tumbled lower to -12.7 from +36.7, below the expected +8.0, marking the survey’s largest ever one month drop. New orders fell to -15.5 from +33.6, while unemployment fell to +4.1 from +9.8, which Pantheon highlights will be followed by a “huge collapse” in April, with the sector in a deep recession for the foreseeable future.

GERMAN IFO Prelim Business Climate Index (Mar) 87.7 (Prev. 96.1, Rev. 96.0); Current Conditions 93.8 (Prev. 98.9, Rev. 99.0); Expectations 82 (Prev. 93.4, Rev. 93.2) - Ifo notes that German economy is falling into recession.

GERMAN DIW INSTITUTE said the virus outbreak is to massively impact the German economy in the next two quarters at lease, could turn out to be much more severe if uncertainty persists, German economy to shrink 0.1% in 2020 assuming optimistic V-shaped recovery.

EQUITIES:

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.66% at 2,414, NDX +1.58% at 7,289, DJIA +0.95% at 20,087.

SECTORS: Energy +6.75%, Cons Disc +3.4%, Financials +2.25%, Materials +2.22%, Communication Svs +1.66%, Technology +1.11%, Industrials +0.33%, Real Estate -1.35%, Health -1.87%, Cons Stpl -2.91%, Utilities -5.47%.        

STOCK SPECIFICS: On a broader theme, US President Trump said he does not want government aid to go to buybacks, noting he is not happy with buybacks.  Trump later added that he would support the government an equity stake in some companies, saying aid is coming to airlines, cruise operators and hotels. Gilead (GILD) saw choppy trade amid US President Trump's coronavirus briefing which saw the name fall slightly as Trump made suggestions to other drugs being potentially used to help treat coronavirus patients, although quickly spiked on comments of promising therapies produced by GILD, albeit gains were short-lived. Moderna (MRNA) sunk after the FDA announced a vaccine trial is to take 1 year.  Uber (UBER) saw heavy gains after comments from its CEO that it expects to have USD 6bln cash in hand by the end of the year with a USD 2bln revolving credit facility. CEO Khosrowshai, however, did note that its rides segment is seeing a 60-70% decline in the areas hit the worst from coronavirus, although it has plenty of cash to get through the crisis. WSJ sources noted Boeing (BA) is considering a dividend cut and possibly layoffs at its jetliner plans as it deals with the airline pressure from COVID-19. Meanwhile, CNBC noted lawmakers are reportedly wary of bailing out Boeing. Accenture (ACN) saw solid gains after a reporting solid revenue, while EPS was in line. Meanwhile, Occidental Petroleum (OXY) managed to hold onto gains as oil prices bounce from prior day losses despite a debt downgrade to Junk from Moody’s. Tiffany’s (TIF) surged in late trade after reports suggested LVMH (MC FP) is to consider purchasing TIF shares on the open market. 

CRUDE:

SETTLEMENT: WTI (J0) SETTLES USD 4.85 HIGHER (+23.81%) AT USD 25.22/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLES USD 3.59 HIGHER (+14.43%) AT USD 28.47/BBL.

Crude benchmarks bounced from the prior day declines where WTI outperformed Brent seeing the Arb narrow to just over 2 dollars from 5 the prior day - also marking WTI's largest ever one-day percentage gain. The crude complex found some support from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin who stated the DoE is looking to purchase between USD 10-20bln worth of oil at low prices; more specifically, the DoE said it would buy 30mln bbls of crude by March 26th to add to the SPR while oil prices are low and it is to add the remainder of the 77mln bbls at a later date. Meanwhile, Shell (RDSA. LN) chartered a second supertanker at sea to store another 2mln bbls of oil to take advantage of the steeper contango across the term structure. Risk sentiment improved somewhat following the steep declines yesterday with equities trading in positive territory with gains being led by energy companies. Saudi Aramco stated it will carry on reducing operation levels at local refineries in April and May to bolster its export potential. Meanwhile, the Algeria Energy Minister stated there are signs oil demand will improve during H2 which will lift oil prices.  Analysts at Citi highlight that although a bounce was seen today, it remains fragile, and the desk believes policy measures from monetary and fiscal side are welcome but “policymakers may simply lack the precision tools required to address the specific impact of the crisis”, highlighting lower US gasoline retail sales even before travel restrictions. The desk notes none of the proposals would directly put drivers back on the road.

POST SETTLEMENT: Texas was reportedly mulling the curtailment of oil production for the first time in decades, according to WSJ citing sources.

BONDS

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 1 POINT 4+ TICKS HIGHER AT 135-07.

THE TPLEX BULL STEEPENED after a recent acute sell-off in duration, alongside a bounce in equities. Desks note the improved risk sentiment and incoming fiscal and monetary stimulus has likely put a pause in forced liquidations in DM bonds. Furthermore, the Fed has been ramping up its Treasury purchases – with USD 100bln scheduled for purchase across Thursday and Friday. A large deluge of IG corporate supply didn’t buck the trend either after recent dry spells. By settlement, 10s -0.11bps at 1.147%, 2s -0.08bps at 0.448%, leaving the 2s10s at 69.20.

US SELLS USD 12BLN OF 10-YEAR TIPS at a high yield of 0.680% (prev. 0.036%). B/C: 2.32x (prev. 2.33x). Dealers: 19.7% (prev. 15.4%). Directs: 17.0% (prev. 11.5%). Indirects: 63.3% (prev. 73.2%).

BREXIT:

UK PM Johnson spokesperson said the UK has been in close contact with EU to continue to progress negotiations. The European Commission said the EU-UK negotiations on ties following Brexit will be brought forward even in the current circumstances.

FOREX:

The dollar continued its gains with DXY crossing 102.50 likely aided by the weaker Euro amid the ECB’s PEPP and as dollar demand continues to hold narrative while Gold continues its decline beneath 1500/oz. GBP initially found support from the emergency BoE rate cut and stimulus package after falling to lows not seen since the 1980s yesterday however Cable saw downside heading in the London fix which saw demand for the buck drive price action which saw cable fall back beneath 1.16 to similar levels yesterday. EURUSD fell beneath 1.07 amid the ECB’s EUR 750bln PEPP while noting that more can be done if necessary. Citi notes it continues to expect a significant response in the Eurozone, while the ball is now in the hands of the fiscal government. JPY continued to weaken against the greenback amid broad dollar strength. Meanwhile, the BoJ purchased JPY 1trln JGB’s to stem the rising bond yields in an unscheduled purchase. As risk appetite fared better on Thursday AUD & NZD were slightly firmer against a surging buck amid a 25bps rate cut from the RBA as expected while also initiating YCC (as inferred by Governor Debelle’s recent speech) by targeting the 3-year yield at 0.25%. The RBA decision saw limited reaction, although the Aussie and Kiwi benefited after the Federal Reserve expanded its US dollar swap line to RBA and RBNZ among others helping the Banks fund its dollar needs; It was also expanded to Norges Bank, Riksbank, BoK, Banxico, BCB, Danish and Singapore Central Bank. NOK traded firmer after the central bank announced it may intervene in FX markets following “historically large” weakness in the NOK, while noting it is continuously considering whether there is a need to intervene in the market by purchasing NOK. EURSEK weaker amid the fall in the single currency and from the US dollar swap line expansion. Petro-currencies were supported by the rebound in oil prices, although USDCAD remains flat given the rising dollar. Whereas RUB outperformed EMFX counterparts and is back beneath 80.00 against the greenback. TRY however fell victim to the rising oil prices. ZAR weakened after its deeper than expected unanimous 100bps rate cut, while also announcing it expects GDP to contract 0.2% in 2020 from its prior estimate of +1.2%. USDBRL saw choppy trade where the BCB unanimously cut its Selic rate by 50bps, deeper than the 25bps expected which saw USDBRL gap higher at the open, although trended lower to flat levels as trade progressed.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Antipodes assuaged by Fed swaps, Sterling takes BoE stimulus in stride
content:
AUD/NZD/NOK/SEK/GBP/CAD

Almost a classic tale of 2 halves for the Aussie and Kiwi that are back on or near the 0.5900 handle vs their US counterpart, and well off overnight lows around 0.5508 and 0.5472 respectively. A broad upturn in risk sentiment (albeit ultimately after latest wild fluctuations) has helped the Antipodean Dollars claw back more of their recent losses, and Wednesday’s especially hefty declines, but the real game-changer appeared to be the Fed extending and expanding swap lines to the likes of the RBA and RBNZ. Similarly, the Norwegian and Swedish Krona are benefiting from direct Usd funding facilities and indirectly from the Euro’s demise, while signals from the Norges Bank about potential intervention on top of larger daily foreign currency purchases for budget purposes plus a decent rebound in oil prices are also supporting the Nok. Elsewhere, the Pound was already on the comeback trail after a woeful Wednesday, but Cable hit near 1.1800 recovery peaks and Eur/Gbp recoiled to circa 0.9124 even though the BoE held another extraordinary policy meeting to lower the Bank rate from 0.25% to 0.1% (base for the MPC) and unveil an extra Gbp200 bn APF. Meanwhile, the aforementioned recovery in crude has cushioned the Loonie from the worst of the Greenback’s ongoing rally as Usd/Cad consolidates around 1.4500 despite the DXY climbing briefly crossing 102.5000.

EUR/JPY/CHF

In stark contrast to all the above, Euro, Yen and Franc depreciation has accelerated throughout Thursday’s EU session, with Eur/Usd now sub-1.0700, Usd/Jpy clearly through 110.00 and Usd/Chf over 0.9850. The single currency has been undermined independently by the ongoing spread of nCoV across the bloc and yet more economic evidence of its toll via Ifo and drastic downgrades to GDP projections, while the BoJ continues to increase ETF purchases and the SNB raised its assessment of the Franc to even more highly valued after maintaining benchmark rates, but lifting NIRP exemptions for banks and stating that it has been compelled to intervene more.

EM

Aside from all else, the Rand has had digested aggressive SARB action in the form of a full point rate cut vs -50 bp expected, but the Rouble has gleaned traction from a Brent revival and CBR intervention. Hence, Usd/Zar surpassing 17.5000 at one stage, while Usd/Rub has drifted back from around 81.9080.

19th March 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1300GMT/0900CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

  • Of note for Hotel Names (H, MAR, HLT), NYC officials are reportedly working with hotel officials to potentially convert entire hotels into hospitals for patients without the coronavirus, according to WSJ. Elsewhere, the American Hotel and Lodging Association President and CEO stated “more than half of the hotels across America will close by the end of the month. Whether or not the closure is permanent or temporary. Some of it will be permanent”, according to FBN.
  • Of note for Automakers (GM, F, TSLA), GM and F have been in talks with government officials on how it could support the production of medical equipment to help tackle the coronavirus outbreak. Tesla CEO Musk also announced in a tweet “We will make ventilators if there is a shortage”.

Dow Jones

  • Pfizer (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announce it has postponed its investor day due to the coronavirus, although a specific date is not mentioned due to uncertainty surrounding the coronavirus. Although it did announce its late stage study of an experimental treatment, abrocitinib, was effective in treating atopic dermatitis in a combination with topical therapies. It also reported positive top line results from its pneumococcal conjugate vaccine in adult patients.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) announced US stores will adjust its operating hours to 07:00 to 20:30 to increase cleaning and allow more time for its stock to be stacked.

Nasdaq 100

  • Align Technology (ALGN) (Health Care/Health Care Supplies) announced as the coronavirus spreads to Europe, Middle East, Africa and Americas, it is expecting a material impact from the virus on its Q120 results.
  • eBay Inc. (EBAY) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) – One of its largest shareholders, Starboard Value, announced it has delivered a formal notice to nominate four directors to the company board.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) CEO Zuckerberg dismissed the Washington Post report yesterday that the government is working with tech companies to use location data to tackle the coronavirus.
  • Marriott Int'l. (MAR) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) announced it has been implementing cost cutting measures, including shortened work weeks and pay cuts to senior executives. So far, the measures will reduce 2020 corporate general and administrative costs by at least USD 140mln. MAR also expects to eliminate or defer at least one third of its USD 700-800mln spending plans for 2020. It also notes as of March 17th it has drawn down USD 2.5bln of it USD 4.5bln revolving credit facility to support commercial paper maturities. It expects its latest dividend to be the last the conditions get better. Given the mentioned commitments the Co is facing, it has decided to withdraw all aspects of its outlook and assumptions for FY20. Elsewhere, it says there are early signs of improvement in China and the number of closed hotels in the region has fallen to under 30 from 90 previously.
  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) CEO announced on CNBC 95% of its China stores are expected to open by the end of the month, noting the “to go” model is working in both the US and China.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) Fremont Factory in California will reportedly stay open, but at a limited capacity. Reports earlier in the week noted it had been ordered to halt operations temporarily amid the coronavirus pandemic. Elsewhere, the automaker was also upgraded to Equal Weight from Underweight at Morgan Stanley, where analyst Adam Jonas gives a USD 460 PT (Prev. close 361.22), where the analyst notes TSLA has sufficient cash and liquidity available to help against near term disruptions to its production and sales.
  • T-Mobile (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) announced it is currently financially prepared to close its merger with Sprint (S).
  • Trip.com (TCOM) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. earnings per ADS 0.28, revenue 1.2bln (+10% Y/Y). Q1 revenue view -45 to 50%.

S&P 500

  • Abbott Laboratories (ABT) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) announced the US FDA issued an emergency use authorisation for its coronavirus test.
  • Accenture plc (ACN) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) Q2 20 (USD): EPS 1.91 (exp. 1.72), revenue 11.1bln (exp. 11.1bln), new bookings 14.2bln. Q3 revenue view 10.75-11.15bln (exp. 11.74bln). Cut its FY20 EPS view to 7.48-7.70 (exp. 7.84, prev. 7.66-7.84).
  • Darden Restaurants (DRI) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) Q3 EPS 1.90 (exp. 1.88), revenue 2.35bln (exp. 2.32bln); Same restaurant sales +2.3%. Withdraws FY20 guidance and announced it has suspended its quarterly dividend amid the coronavirus outbreak.
  • Diamondback Energy (FANG) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) announced it has cut activity even further. Due to the reduction in activity It expects to reduce its capital budget for this year by USD 1.2bln to USD 1.5-1.9bln from USD 2.8-3.0bln. 
  • Estee Lauder Cos. (EL) (Consumer Staples/Personal Products) announced it has withdrawing its FY20 guidance.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) Healthcare CEO issued a statement noting it has increased its manufacturing capacity and output of equipment to help with diagnosis and treatment of patients with coronavirus. Adding it is continuously exploring options to support the increased need of medical equipment.
  • Harley-Davidson (HOG) (Consumer Discretionary/Motorcycle Manufacturers) announced it is temporarily suspending the majority of its US operations and the majority of its production employees will be on temporary layoff with medical benefits. Elsewhere, Impala Asset Management nominated two candidates to its board of directors.
  • Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) (Financials/Financial Exchanges & Data) announced the NYSE will move temporality to fully electronic trading as of Monday the 23rd.
  • Lennar Corp. (LEN) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 1.27 (exp. 0.84), Revenue 4.5bln (exp. 4.16bln). Deliveries +17% to 10321 homes, Backlog +2% to 17,632. New orders +18% to 12,376 homes.
  • Marathon Petroleum (MPC) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) reportedly begun cutting production on Wednesday as demand for motor fuels in the Los Angeles area collapses, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • Occidental Petroleum (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) had its debt rating downgraded to Junk, noting credit challenges ahead following the collapse in energy prices.
  • TripAdvisor (TRIP) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) announced it has withdrawn its guidance for FY20 due to the coronavirus.
  • Twitter, Inc. (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is reportedly being used by the FDA to stay updated with medical and drug supply issues, according to Politico.

Other

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 19th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment was bolstered on the ECB measures; but failed to hold to the optimism
  • ECB announced EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme, conducted until end-2020
  • Fed announced to launch mutual money market fund facility to lend to financial institutions
  • RBA lowered Cash Rate Target by 25bps to 0.25% and announced QE as speculated
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Initial Jobless Claims, SARB Monetary Policy Announcements

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 34 additional cases of coronavirus and 8 additional deaths on March 18th vs. Prev. 13 additional cases and 11 additional deaths on March 17th to brings total mainland cases to 80928 and death toll at 3245. (Newswires) Note: the numbers arose from imported cases as opposed to local cases.

China to step up fiscal stimulus including infrastructure investment (such as 5G networks) and is considering plans to cut its 2020 growth target to as low as 5% from 6% agreed in Dec. (Newswires)

Italy coronavirus cases rose to 35713 (Prev. 31506) and the death toll rose by 475 to 2978. (Newswires)

German Coronavirus cases to 10999 from 8198 (+2801), according to RKI Health Institute. (Newswires)

-        German Ministers are yet to sign off on the EUR 40bln support package for small/medium Co's, could be in excess of EUR 40bln, according to Gov't sources

South Korea reported 152 additional coronavirus cases to take total to 8565 and deaths increased by 7 to a total of 91, while there were an additional 407 that fully recovered to bring the total to 1947. (Newswires)

California Governor says modelling shows 60k homeless in the state could contract coronavirus over next 8 weeks

US President Trump tweeted that he only signed the Defense Production Act to combat the Chinese Virus should we need to invoke it in a worst-case scenario in the future, although he added that hopefully there will be no need. (Twitter)

Italy are to extend virus lockdown measures, according to PM Conte cited by AFP. (Twitter) French Interior Minister says the Government will extend the lockdown period if it is necessary. (Newswires)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier has tested positive for the coronavirus. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB announced EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) in which it will launch a new temporary asset purchase programme of private and public sector securities to counter serious risks to monetary policy transmission mechanism. Purchases will be conducted until the end of 2020 and will include all the asset categories eligible under the existing asset purchase programme (APP). Furthermore, the GC said it is fully prepared to raise size of programmes, as well as adjust composition by as much as necessary and for as long as needed. A waiver of the eligibility requirements for securities issued by the Greek government will be granted for purchases under PEPP. (ECB) Link to release

ECB's Lagarde said extraordinary times require extraordinary action, while she added there are no limits to our commitment to the Euro and are determined to use full potential of all our tools within our mandate. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy said ECB is absolutely determined to fight fragmentation risk between Eurozone countries and noted it will buy more bonds if needed in this exceptional period, while he also stated that French banks are solid and do not need nationalisation. (Newswires)

Fed announced to launch mutual money market fund facility to lend to financial institutions which it said will help meet demands for redemptions by households and other investors to enhance credit provisions throughout the economy.  Furthermore, the program includes USD 10bln of credit protection from US Treasury Exchange Stabilization Fund. (Newswires)

New York Fed plans to purchase USD 100bln in Treasury purchases over Thursday and Friday. (Newswires)

SNB left Policy Rate unchanged at -0.75% as expected, CHF is “even more highly valued” vs. Prev. “highly valued”; SNB is intervening even more in FX markets. SNB is raising the exemption threshold as of 1 April 2020, thus reducing the negative interest burden on the banking system. The threshold factor will increase from 25 to 30. SNB is examining whether a relaxation of the countercyclical capital buffer would be possible despite the risks on the mortgage and real estate markets. The SNB will take additional steps to ensure liquidity as necessary. Even under this assumption, however, GDP growth is likely to be negative for the year as a whole. The return to normality from the second half of the year onwards could thereafter be reflected in strong positive growth in 2021. (SNB)

SNB Governor Jordan: SNB can cut interest rates further in the future but it is unfavourable at the moment, Switzerland is not a currency manipulator; SNB does not intervene to get an advantage vs. other countries. Notes, there is no co-ordinated measures with other central banks. Talks are ongoing with Swiss Govt but its too early to give details of further supportive steps (Newswires)

Norges Bank state that, due to the recent moves in the NOK, they may intervene in the market via the purchase of NOK; are to offer extraordinary F-loans to banks, as of March 19th; will have a 1-week, 1-month, 3, 6 & 12 month maturities; all will be fully allotted (Norges Bank)

RBA lowered Cash Rate Target by 25bps to 0.25% and announced to buy government bonds in secondary market as speculated, which will commence on Friday. Furthermore, the RBA announced to offer 3yr funding (TFF) to authorized deposit taking institutions with the facility valued at least AUD 90bln, while it stated that banks will have access to additional low-cost funding if they expand lending to businesses. (Newswires)

BoJ January Meeting Minutes noted that most members stated they must be mindful of downside risks to the economy but momentum for hitting price target is sustained. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets extended on losses with price action turbulent as ongoing coronavirus fears and disruptions, which now threatens to lockdown New York and London, offset the various global policy efforts to tackle the fallout including the ECB announcement of a EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme and RBA rate cut with QE. The announcement by the ECB initially boosted US equity futures and propelled Euro Stoxx 50 futures higher by over 3%, although the momentum then waned which fully wiped out the earlier gains. ASX 200 (-3.4%) swung between gains and losses heading into the off-schedule RBA monetary policy announcement which despite the RBA actions, did little to support the Australian benchmark which was heavily pressured by a collapse in the real estate sector, energy and financials. Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) also gave back opening gains with Tokyo exporters weighed by the safe haven flows into the domestic currency and with participants diminishing risk ahead of tomorrow’s holiday closure. Hang Seng (-2.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) were subdued as the coronavirus jitters continue to ruffle markets and as earnings also entered the fray including Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent which missed on its Q4 net. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued and continued to test support at 151.00 where prices have found a base. The BoJ were also active in the market today in which it announced 2 unscheduled special operations to purchase a total of JPY 1.3tln of JGBs although this only briefly underpinned prices, while Japanese CPI data and outdated BoJ minutes from the January meeting were largely ignored given that the data was mixed and meeting was prior to the blow up of the coronavirus pandemic.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0522 vs. Exp. 7.0486 (Prev. 7.0328)

Japanese National CPI (Feb) Y/Y 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Feb) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.8%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Feb) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.8%)

Japanese Bank lobby head said the economy has been impacted more seriously by the coronavirus than was expected. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Whitehall sources said most shops could close and transport could be restricted in London by the weekend under plans being considered by UK Government. (Sky News)

Transport for London adjusted its service operations in which it will shut the Waterloo & City Line and close up to 40 stations, as well as suspend the night tube and night overground although night buses will still operate for essential journeys. (Sky News)

EU Market Watchdog states that effective start of reporting requirements for securities finance transaction are to be delayed to July (3-month delay) due to the outbreak. (Newswres)

German Ifo Prelim Business Climate Index (Mar) 87.7 (Prev. 96.1, Rev. 96.0); Current Conditions 93.8 (Prev. 98.9, Rev. 99.0); Expectations 82 (Prev. 93.4, Rev. 93.2) - Ifo notes that German economy is falling into recession. (Newswires)

German DIW Institute says virus outbreak is to massively impact German economy in the next two quarters at lease, could turn out to be much more severe if uncertainty persists, German economy to shrink 0.1% in 2020 assuming optimistic V-shaped recovery. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses trade mixed having waned off earlier highs [Eurostoxx 50 Unch] after sentiment in the equity sphere was bolstered by ECB’s EUR 750bln PEPP announcement, which at the time prompted European stock futures high and US futures to follow suit, although

the latter failed to climb to positive territory. UK’s FTSE 100 (-1.7%) lags despite the GBP weakening to multi-decade lows, as the announced European package failed to reverberate into the sentiment across the channel. Meanwhile the DAX 30 (-0.6%) lost steam amid a bleak Ifo Survey and a string of downbeat economic forecasts from various institutes, all forecasting a 2020 German recession. Italy’s FTSE MIB (+2.1%) remains underpinned by the 3-month long short ban sale coupled with the ECB announcement. European sectors are all higher and largely reflect risk appetite, although Consumer Staples and Telecoms outperform given as the ongoing lockdown prompts additional broadband usage and stockpiling of staple goods. Swiss Banks meanwhile received a fleeting boost in light of the SNB monetary policy announcement in which it sweetened its tiering terms to a multiple of 30x from 25x, Swiss Banks remain supported with UBS higher to the tune of 7%. In terms of individual movers, Next (+13.0%) shares are supported post-earnings.

FX                        

USD - In spite of concerted if not quite coordinated attempts to intervene, the Greenback remains on an upward trajectory and extending gains vs all G10 counterparts plus the bulk of EM currencies, with very few exceptions, like the Rouble that has clawed back some losses following CBR buying aimed at preventing Brent and Ural crude from caving too far below Usd25/brl. Indeed, the DXY has just posted a new ytd peak at 102.020 and closer to the next bullish technical objective at 102.260.

NZD/JPY/EUR/AUD/CHF/GBP - All trailing further behind the Buck, as the Kiwi lags within a gaping 0.5472-0.5748 range and Yen loses even more of its safe-haven premium alongside Gold between 109.55-107.87 parameters. Meanwhile, the Euro is testing bids/support around the 1.0800 handle in wake of another bleak German business survey (Ifo echoing downbeat ZEW sentiment readings) and multi GDP downgrades via economic institutes, and the Aussie is languishing just above 0.5700 after RBA QE and more emergency funding, albeit off worst levels close to 0.5500 at one stage overnight. Elsewhere, the Franc is still mixed around 0.9750 and 1.0550 against the single currency following the SNB maintaining policy and only reinforcing NIRP intentions alongside stronger FX interventions despite upgrading its valuation of the unit to even more high from high. Last, but by no means least, scant reprieve for Sterling as Cable only clambers back from circa 1.1475 lows to 1.1500 awaiting a probable London lockdown and a likely further delay to Brexit negotiations resuming given that the EU’s chief representative Barnier contracting COVID-19.

CAD/SCANDI/EM - The Loonie is doing better than most to resist its US peer’s advances, but still prone either side of 1.4500 if oil prices tank again and/or risk aversion really picks up, in the same vein as the Norwegian and Swedish Crowns as the former has only gleaned a degree of support from the Norges Bank hinting an direct intervention to supplement increased regular daily foreign currency purchases announced yesterday. As noted above, the Rub is the notable ‘outperformer’, though not before more pronounced weakness that triggered CBR action, while the Zar is trading defensively in the run up to the SARB that is expected to cut rates by 50 bp.

FIXED INCOME

UK debt has been underperforming since Liffe resumed, but the 10 year bond is now diverging further in wake a so-so DMO auction and as Britain braces for more extreme preparations/contagion from nCoV. Gilts are threatening to lose the 129.00 handle in contrast to Bunds keeping afloat of 169.00, albeit well off best levels above 171.00 and US Treasuries hold close to 135-00+ recovery highs.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures experience a day of reprieve in the aftermath of the 24% drop in prices in the prior session – with underlying themes still failing to fade but with sentiment supported by the ECB’s PEPP announcement. WTI has clambered of its near-multi-decade low after testing USD 20/bbl to the downside, whilst its Brent counterpart drifts closer to the USD 25/bbl, albeit ultimately in positive territory on the day. Meanwhile, spot gold remains sub-1500/ozwith prices subdued amid the flight for cash. The yellow metal meanders around 1475/oz in early EU trade and sees a recent low at USD 1452/oz. Finally, copper prices see detrimental downside amid the overall demand implications of the virus and a firmer Buck. The red metal briefly gave up the USD 2/bl level during overnight trade before trimming some losses as European players entered the market.

subject: German government want to apply an exception to the debt brake rule that could happen at the Cabinet meeting on Monday, according to sources cited by Handelsblatt
content:
• Decision must be granted by the majority of Bundestag members
  • For small businesses, equipment aids worth several thousand Euros are being discussed

subject: FX Morning Colour: Dollar impregnable to (almost) all forms of intervention
content:
USD

In spite of concerted if not quite coordinated attempts to intervene, the Greenback remains on an upward trajectory and extending gains vs all G10 counterparts plus the bulk of EM currencies, with very few exceptions, like the Rouble that has clawed back some losses following CBR buying aimed at preventing Brent and Ural crude from caving too far below Usd25/brl. Indeed, the DXY has just posted a new ytd peak at 102.020 and closer to the next bullish technical objective at 102.260.

NZD/JPY/EUR/AUD/CHF/GBP

All trailing further behind the Buck, as the Kiwi lags within a gaping 0.5472-0.5748 range and Yen loses even more of its safe-haven premium alongside Gold between 109.55-107.87 parameters. Meanwhile, the Euro is testing bids/support around the 1.0800 handle in wake of another bleak German business survey (Ifo echoing downbeat ZEW sentiment readings) and multi GDP downgrades via economic institutes, and the Aussie is languishing just above 0.5700 after RBA QE and more emergency funding, albeit off worst levels close to 0.5500 at one stage overnight. Elsewhere, the Franc is still mixed around 0.9750 and 1.0550 against the single currency following the SNB maintaining policy and only reinforcing NIRP intentions alongside stronger FX interventions despite upgrading its valuation of the unit to even more high from high. Last, but by no means least, scant reprieve for Sterling as Cable only clambers back from circa 1.1475 lows to 1.1500 awaiting a probable London lockdown and a likely further delay to Brexit negotiations resuming given that the EU’s chief representative Barnier has contracted COVID-19.

CAD/SCANDI/EM

The Loonie is doing better than most to resist its US peer’s advances, but still prone either side of 1.4500 if oil prices tank again and/or risk aversion really picks up, in the same vein as the Norwegian and Swedish Crowns as the former has only gleaned a degree of support from the Norges Bank hinting an direct intervention to supplement increased regular daily foreign currency purchases announced yesterday. As noted above, the Rub is the notable ‘outperformer’, though not before more pronounced weakness that triggered CBR action, while the Zar is trading defensively in the run up to the SARB that is expected to cut rates by 50 bp.

subject: SNB leaves Policy Rate unchanged at -0.75% as expected, CHF is “even more highly valued” vs. Prev. “highly valued”; SNB is intervening even more in FX markets
content:
• SNB is raising the exemption threshold as of 1 April 2020, thus reducing the negative interest burden on the banking system. The threshold factor will increase from 25 to 30.
  • The Swiss financial system has sufficient liquidity. The SNB will take additional steps to ensure liquidity as necessary.
  • SNB is examining whether a relaxation of the countercyclical capital buffer would be possible despite the risks on the mortgage and real estate markets.
  • The conditional inflation forecast is based on the assumption that the SNB policy rate remains at –0.75% over the entire forecast horizon.
  • Even under this assumption, however, GDP growth is likely to be negative for the year as a whole. The return to normality from the second half of the year onwards could thereafter be reflected in strong positive growth in 2021.
  • Link
reaction_details:
• CHF was quite choppy upon the announcement before weakening in which EUR/CHF rose from 1.0560 to 1.0584
  • Swiss Banks rose upon the sweetened exemption threshold

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
19th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA Asian equity markets extended on losses with price action turbulent as ongoing coronavirus fears and disruptions, which now threatens to lockdown New York and London, offset the various global policy efforts to tackle the fallout including the ECB announcement of a EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme and RBA rate cut with QE. The announcement by the ECB initially boosted US equity futures and propelled Euro Stoxx 50 futures higher by over 3%, although the momentum then waned which fully wiped out the earlier gains. ASX 200 (-1.0%) swung between gains and losses heading into the off-schedule RBA monetary policy announcement which despite the RBA actions, did little to support the Australian benchmark which was heavily pressured by a collapse in the real estate sector, energy and financials. Nikkei 225 (-2.5%) also gave back opening gains with Tokyo exporters weighed by the safe haven flows into the domestic currency and with participants diminishing risk ahead of tomorrow’s holiday closure. Hang Seng (-3.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) were subdued as the coronavirus jitters continue to ruffle markets and as earnings also entered the fray including Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent which missed on its Q4 net, while the biggest mover was the Philippines PSEi which dropped as much 24% on resumption from a 2-day halt due to coronavirus concerns and with its capital city currently on lockdown. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued and continued to test support at 151.00 where prices have found a base. The BoJ were also active in the market today in which it announced 2 unscheduled special operations to purchase a total of JPY 1.3tln of JGBs although this only briefly underpinned prices, while Japanese CPI data and outdated BoJ minutes from the January meeting were largely ignored given that the data was mixed and meeting was prior to the blow up of the coronavirus pandemic.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 19th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets extended on losses with price action turbulent amidst ongoing coronavirus fears and disruptions
  • ECB announced EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme, conducted until end-2020
  • Fed announced to launch mutual money market fund facility to lend to financial institutions
  • RBA lowered Cash Rate Target by 25bps to 0.25% and announced QE as speculated
  • In FX, DXY remained firm above 101.00, USD/JPY traded on either side of 109.00, Antipodeans were pressured
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Initial Jobless Claims, SNB & SARB Monetary Policy Announcements, supply from Spain, France and the UK

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 34 additional cases of coronavirus and 8 additional deaths on March 18th vs. Prev. 13 additional cases and 11 additional deaths on March 17th to brings total mainland cases to 80928 and death toll at 3245. (Newswires) Note: the numbers arose from imported cases as opposed to local cases.

Italy coronavirus cases rose to 35713 (Prev. 31506) and the death toll rose by 475 to 2978. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 152 additional coronavirus cases to take total to 8565 and deaths increased by 7 to a total of 91, while there were an additional 407 that fully recovered to bring the total to 1947. (Newswires)

California Governor says modelling shows 60k homeless in the state could contract coronavirus over next 8 weeks

US President Trump tweeted that he only signed the Defense Production Act to combat the Chinese Virus should we need to invoke it in a worst-case scenario in the future, although he added that hopefully there will be no need. (Twitter)

US Senate passed the coronavirus response bill which allows free testing and requires paid sick leave for workers impacted by coronavirus, which US President Trump signed into law. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said the Phase 3 economic relief bill should bring USD 1.3trln worth of stimulus and that the US has enormous resources to deal with distressed industries, while he added that if it takes more than USD 1.3trln worth of stimulus, it will be done and that the government may take equity positions in companies as part of an aid package. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said we will not hesitate to bring further and faster measures where we think it is necessary, while he added the government will rule nothing out when asked about travel restrictions. There were also reports that PM Johnson asked departments to draw up plans for London lockdown in which the Cabinet Office has asked for proposals on restrictions, implementation and compliance measures being called the ‘London Shielding Plan. (Newswires/The Times)

NYSE is to move temporarily to fully electronic trading with equities and options trading floors to temporarily close from Monday 23rd March. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

 

ECB announced EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) in which it will launch a new temporary asset purchase programme of private and public sector securities to counter serious risks to monetary policy transmission mechanism. Purchases will be conducted until the end of 2020 and will include all the asset categories eligible under the existing asset purchase programme (APP). Furthermore, the GC said it is fully prepared to raise size of programmes, as well as adjust composition by as much as necessary and for as long as needed. A waiver of the eligibility requirements for securities issued by the Greek government will be granted for purchases under PEPP. (Newswires) Link to release

ECB's Lagarde said extraordinary times require extraordinary action, while she added there are no limits to our commitment to the Euro and are determined to use full potential of all our tools within our mandate. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy said ECB is absolutely determined to fight fragmentation risk between Eurozone countries and noted it will buy more bonds if needed in this exceptional period, while he also stated that French banks are solid and do not need nationalisation. (Newswires)

Fed announced to launch mutual money market fund facility to lend to financial institutions which it said will help meet demands for redemptions by households and other investors to enhance credit provisions throughout the economy.  Furthermore, the program includes USD 10bln of credit protection from US Treasury Exchange Stabilization Fund. (Newswires)

New York Fed plans to purchase USD 100bln in Treasury purchases over Thursday and Friday. (Newswires)

RBA lowered Cash Rate Target by 25bps to 0.25% and announced to buy government bonds in secondary market as speculated, which will commence on Friday. Furthermore, the RBA announced to offer 3yr funding (TFF) to authorized deposit taking institutions with the facility valued at least AUD 90bln, while it stated that banks will have access to additional low-cost funding if they expand lending to businesses. (Newswires)

BoJ January Meeting Minutes noted that most members stated they must be mindful of downside risks to the economy but momentum for hitting price target is sustained. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets extended on losses with price action turbulent as ongoing coronavirus fears and disruptions, which now threatens to lockdown New York and London, offset the various global policy efforts to tackle the fallout including the ECB announcement of a EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme and RBA rate cut with QE. The announcement by the ECB initially boosted US equity futures and propelled Euro Stoxx 50 futures higher by over 3%, although the momentum then waned which fully wiped out the earlier gains. ASX 200 (-1.0%) swung between gains and losses heading into the off-schedule RBA monetary policy announcement which despite the RBA actions, did little to support the Australian benchmark which was heavily pressured by a collapse in the real estate sector, energy and financials. Nikkei 225 (-2.5%) also gave back opening gains with Tokyo exporters weighed by the safe haven flows into the domestic currency and with participants diminishing risk ahead of tomorrow’s holiday closure. Hang Seng (-3.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) were subdued as the coronavirus jitters continue to ruffle markets and as earnings also entered the fray including Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent which missed on its

Q4 net, while the biggest mover was the Philippines PSEi which dropped as much 24% on resumption from a 2-day halt due to coronavirus concerns and with its capital city currently on lockdown. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued and continued to test support at 151.00 where prices have found a base. The BoJ were also active in the market today in which it announced 2 unscheduled special operations to purchase a total of JPY 1.3tln of JGBs although this only briefly underpinned prices, while Japanese CPI data and outdated BoJ minutes from the January meeting were largely ignored given that the data was mixed and meeting was prior to the blow up of the coronavirus pandemic.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0522 vs. Exp. 7.0486 (Prev. 7.0328)

Japanese National CPI (Feb) Y/Y 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Feb) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.8%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Feb) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.8%)

UK/EU

UK Education Secretary Williamson confirmed schools will remain shut from Friday until further notice. (Newswires)

Whitehall sources said most shops could close and transport could be restricted in London by the weekend under plans being considered by UK Government. (Sky News)

Transport for London adjusted its service operations in which it will shut the Waterloo & City Line and close up to 40 stations, as well as suspend the night tube and night overground although night buses will still operate for essential journeys. (Sky News)

FX

In FX, the DXY remained firm and above the 101.00 handle amid higher yields and as the panic selling across asset classes spurred a demand for cash, while its major counterparts were subdued in which EUR/USD languished around the 1.0900 level after the prior day’s walloping it took against the greenback was eventually eased by support at 1.0800, and the pair also found some brief reprieve from news of the ECB’s Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme. GBP/USD remained subdued around 1.1500 after having slipped to its lowest levels in around 35 years as the coronavirus pandemic threatens to shutdown London. USD/JPY was higher and momentarily broke above 109.00 which was due to the strength of the greenback as most JPY-crosses succumbed to the safe haven flows. Antipodeans nosedived in which AUD/USD and NZD/USD both slipped to test the 0.5500 level amid the spooked risk tone, recent slump in commodities and heading into the RBA decision where it cut rates and announced to conduct QE for the first time as widely speculated. Furthermore, AUD/NZD recently fell below parity for the first time since its float, while better than expected Australian Employment Change and a surprise decline in the Unemployment Rate to 5.1% from 5.3% was largely ignored with participants preferring to focus on the March numbers given the recent substantial industry lay-offs due to coronavirus.

Australian Employment Change (Feb) 26.7k vs. Exp. 10.0k (Prev. 13.5k). (Newswires) Australian Unemployment Rate (Feb) 5.1% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.3%) Australian Full-Time Employment Change (Feb) 6.7k (Prev. 46.2k)

New Zealand GDP (Q4) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.7%, Rev. 0.8%). (Newswires) New Zealand GDP (Q4) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 2.3%)

Brazilian central bank lowered the Selic rate by 50bs to 3.75% as speculated. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly weaker amid the continued sell-off across global markets as investors ploughed into the greenback which saw gold prices slip further away from the USD 1500/oz level, while copper also took a hit overnight on the spooked risk sentiment and amid heavy selling of commodities as Shanghai metals trade got underway in which Shanghai front month copper prices declined around 9% at the open. Conversely, WTI crude futures saw some reprieve overnight with gains of nearly 12%, although it still has far to go to recoup the prior session’s 24% drop in prices to its lowest since 2002 where it briefly tested USD 20/bbl amid the panic selling across markets and reports that Saudi’s Energy Minister directed Aramco to continue supplying crude at a rate of 12.3mln BPD over the coming month.

US

The TPLEX continued its bear steepener amid a flight to cash seen across all major assets. The offer was most severe in APAC trade as US equity futures hit their limit down. The lift in equities after the US cash open also saw some support for the TPLEX, although ultimately proved short-lived. In the background participants are digesting the mass global fiscal stimulus packages being proposed, which will ramp-up supply. Furthermore, desks note the continued unwind of relative value and basis trades that have been blown up lately, in addition to wider profit-taking in the context of the pronounced drop in rates in the wake of the virus outbreak. By settlement, 2s/10s +7bps to around 63bps, levels not seen since 2018, with the 10-year yield +16bps to 1.16%; note that the 30-year yield reached close to 2% at one point. T-note futures (H0) settled 1 point 22 ticks lower at 134-12.

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks declined in a turbulent session amid lockdown concerns
content: Asia equity markets extended on losses with price action turbulent as ongoing coronavirus fears and disruptions, which now threatens to lockdown New York and London, offset the various global policy efforts to tackle the fallout including the ECB announcement of a EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme and RBA rate cut with QE. The announcement by the ECB initially boosted US equity futures and propelled Euro Stoxx 50 futures higher by over 3%, although the momentum then waned which fully wiped out the earlier gains. ASX 200 (-1.0%) swung between gains and losses heading into the off-schedule RBA monetary policy announcement which despite the RBA actions, did little to support the Australian benchmark which was heavily pressured by a collapse in the real estate sector, energy and financials. Nikkei 225 (-2.5%) also gave back opening gains with Tokyo exporters weighed by the safe haven flows into the domestic currency and with participants paring risk ahead of tomorrow’s holiday closure. Hang Seng (-3.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) were subdued as the coronavirus jitters continue to ruffle markets and as earnings also entered the fray including Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent which missed on its Q4 net, while the biggest mover was the Philippines PSEi which dropped as much 24% on resumption from a 2-day halt due to coronavirus concerns and with its capital city currently on lockdown. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued and continued to test support at 151.00 where prices have found a base. The BoJ were also active in the market today in which it announced 2 unscheduled special operations to purchase a total of JPY 1.3tln of JGBs although this only briefly underpinned prices, while Japanese CPI data and outdated BoJ minutes from the January meeting were largely ignored given that the data was mixed and meeting was prior to the blow up of the coronavirus pandemic.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks decline in a turbulent session amid lockdown concerns
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly lower with price action turbulent as ongoing coronavirus fears and disruptions, which now threatens to lockdown New York and London, has offset the various global policy efforts to tackle the fallout including the latest by the ECB which unveiled a EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme. The announcement initially boosted US equity futures and propelled Euro Stoxx 50 futures higher by over 3%, although the momentum has since waned and the earlier gains fully retraced. ASX 200 (-1.9%) swung between gains and losses as the looming off-schedule RBA monetary policy announcement added to the cautiousness. Nikkei 225 (-2.5%) also gave back opening gains as it was weighed by the safe haven flows into the domestic currency and with participants paring risk ahead of tomorrow’s holiday closure. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-5.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.6%) are subdued as the coronavirus jitters continue to ruffle markets and with earnings also entering the fray including Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent which missed on its Q4 net, while the biggest mover was the Philippines PSEi which dropped as much 24% on resumption from a 2-day halt due to coronavirus concerns and with its capital city currently on lockdown.

In FX markets, the DXY remains firm and above the 101.00 handle amid higher yields and as the panic selling across asset classes spurred a demand for cash, while its major counterparts are subdued as EUR/USD is flat around the 109.00 level after the prior day’s walloping it took against the greenback was eventually eased by support at 1.0800, and the pair also found some brief reprieve from news of the ECB’s Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme. GBP/USD remains subdued around 1.1500 after having slipped to its lowest levels in around 35 years as the coronavirus pandemic threatens to shutdown London. USD/JPY is higher and broke above 109.00 which is due to the strength of the greenback as most JPY-crosses succumb to the safe haven flows. Antipodeans nosedived in which AUD/USD and NZD/USD both slipped to test the 0.5500 level amid the spooked risk tone, recent slump in commodities and ahead of a potential RBA rate cut and/or unprecedented QE announcement. Furthermore, AUD/NZD fell below parity for the first time since its float, while better than expected Australian Employment Change and a surprise decline in the Unemployment Rate to 5.1% from 5.3% was largely ignored ahead of the RBA and with participants preferring to focus on the March numbers given the recent substantial industry lay-offs from the coronavirus fallout.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued but off lows after finding support at 151.00 and with the BoJ also announcing an unscheduled Rinban operation of JPY 1tln, with price action relatively stable after mixed CPI data and outdated BoJ minutes from the January meeting which was prior to the blow up of the coronavirus pandemic.
